dek: How famous people are remembered (or not) after they die.

prelude.value: When a famous person dies, articles are written, tweets are tweeted, and Wikipedia is updated.

prelude2.value: Why do people care so much when a famous person dies?

After Anthony Bourdain died, it felt like everyone (myself included) could talk about nothing else. It was both sad and unexpected. But it wasn’t just him. I could rattle off a dozen other recent deaths that seemed to eclipse the rest of the news cycle.

We develop special relationships and often identify with celebrities. That is why Bourdain’s death had such an effect on me. I’ve watched countless hours of him traveling the world, exposing me to a variety of cuisines and cultures.
This connection, in conjunction with the financial incentive for media to get clicks, is a recipe for our undivided attention.

perspectiveSteps.text: How big of a deal is it? To put this in perspective, let’s look at living icon Beyoncé. Here are her (English) Wikipedia pageviews between March and May of 2016, in 48-hour intervals.
On April 24, Beyoncé dropped Lemonade, and the internet went wild. Her pageviews went from an average of 30 thousand to nearly 300 thousand, a tenfold increase.
And now let’s take a look at Prince, starting with the period leading up to his death.
In the 48 hours after Prince’s death was reported, he accumulated over 11 million pageviews on Wikipedia. It was huge news, and was reflected by the pageviews.
Over 1,300 notable people have died in the last three years, according to Wikipedia. Here are 84 that got at least half a million pageviews immediately after their death.
Although no one grabbed our attention quite like Prince, the spikes in pageviews after death can often overshadow major events.

perspectiveNote: Adjusted pageviews are the pageviews scaled to an average day of Wikipedia traffic during the collection period of this data. The remainder of the article will refer to this simply as “pageviews.”

changeIntro.value: After Anthony Bourdain died, it felt like everyone (myself included) could talk about nothing else. It was sad and unexpected. But it wasn’t just him. I could rattle off a dozen other recent deaths that seemed to eclipse the rest of the news cycle.
It makes sense that big names like Prince and Stephen Hawking get the most traffic immediately following their death. But who saw the greatest increase compared to a typical day?

careCaption: “You live only as long as the last person who remembers you.” — Akecheta Westworld

careIntro.value: The first 48 hours only tell us part of the story.  We develop special relationships and often identify with celebrities. That is why Bourdain’s death had such an effect on me. I’ve traveled the world by his side for countless hours.

And now I rewatch him. How (and how long) we pay attention for can give us a different perspective on the impact of their death. Here are the number of weeks after death until pageviews returned to normal.

careNote: A return to normal traffic was considered when the pageviews fell within two standard deviations of the median of the pageviews before the date of death. TBD means they have yet to return to normal.

impactIntro.value: But not everyone’s pageviews do return to normal. At the time of publishing, Bourdain has yet to normalize. Perhaps the person was relatively unknown before, and their death increased their visibility. Or maybe there was a renewed interest in their life’s work. Let’s look at the one-week moving average of the percent increase in pageviews compared to before death.

impactNote: Only including people with data for at least 120 days after their death.

conclusion.value: There many ways to process death. For me, quantifying the public reaction offers a different way to look at these often unexpectedly tragic events.

methodText.value: Data for this story were collected and processed using the Wikipedia API. The yearly aggregation of notable deaths (eg. 2018) was the starting point. The full source and reproducible scripts are available on Github. The development of the entire project was streamed from start to finish. Check it out on YouTube.

The period of collection was from July 1, 2015 - August 1, 2018 from English Wikipedia. Only people with at least 30 days of padding from the edge of this range, hit 500k adjusted pageviews the 48 hours after their death, and had a median 48-hour adjust pageviews of 500+ before death were considered. All pageviews were adjusted to represent traffic on an average day during this period to allow for fair comparison across days.
A return to “normal” traffic was considered when the pageviews fell within two standard deviations of the median of the pageviews before the date of death.
